awd_titl_txt: SBE: Small: The Force of Habit: Using fMRI to Explain Users' Habituation to Security Warnings
awd_abstract_narration:
Warning messages are one of the last lines of defense in computer security, and are fundamental to users' security interactions with technology. Unfortunately, research shows that users routinely ignore security warnings. A key contributor to this disregard is habituation, the diminishing of attention due to frequent exposure. However, previous research examining habituation has done so only indirectly, by observing the influence of habituation on security behavior, rather than measuring habituation itself. This project uses neuroscience to open the "black box" of the brain to observe habituation as it occurs. By investigating how repetition suppression occurs in the brain, researchers can make a more precise approach to designing security warnings that are resistant to the effects of habituation.

Specifically, functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) is used to measure how neural activity in the visual processing centers of the brain sharply decrease with repeated exposure to warnings. This phenomenon, termed the repetition suppression effect, is directly antecedent to the process of habituation. This project aims to: (1) directly measure how habituation of security warnings occurs in the brain; (2) examine how habituation towards security warnings develops over time using a longitudinal design; and (3) use fMRI brain data to guide the design of polymorphic (dynamic) security warnings, as well as to empirically test their effectiveness compared with existing security warnings.  The insights gained from this project have the potential to inform the design and evaluation of warnings that more effectively help users to respond to security threats.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

In this project, we were able to (1) directly measure how habituation of security warnings occurs in the brain—previous studies indirectly measured habituation toward security warnings; (2) with the use of a longitudinal design, examine how habituation toward security warnings develops over time—previous studies were cross-sectional in nature; and (3) use functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) brain data to guide the design of polymorphic (dynamic) security warnings and to empirically test their effectiveness vis-à-vis existing security warnings.

We conducted a series of laboratory experiments to achieve these objectives. We used neuroscience techniques to examine how the repetition suppression effect leads to habituation and to guide the development and testing of security warnings that are resistant to habituation and lead to secure behavior. 

We were able to show that polymorphic warnings, or those that change their appearance, are more resistant to habituation, or tuning out, than are the standard warnings. In addition, our longitudinal studies show that these polymorphic warnings are more resistant to habituation even across multiple days and weeks. In our longitudinal study using fMRI and eye tracking, Figure 1 shows the amount of attention paid to the warnings as measured by eye fixations. The attention to the polymorphic warnings (shown in red) is higher than the static or traditional warnings over the course of a week. Figure 2 shows the areas of the brain affected by the habituation effect over time. In a follow-up longitudinal study using Android mobile devices, we found a similar trend of polymorphic warnings showing a resistance to habituation over the course of three weeks as shown in Figure 3.

 

Broader Impact 

Users remain the weak link in computer security partly because of their inability to appropriately respond to security warnings. The insights gained from this proposal helps us inform the design and evaluation of warnings to effectively help users respond to security threats and thus enhance the information security of individuals, and organizations.

We provided a mentored environment for both graduate and undergraduate students. These students were cross-disciplinary, from neuroscience and psychology, to business and information systems. We had student collaboration on all aspects of research, including design, experimentation, data analysis, writing, and presenting at conferences. This type of interaction has been proven to be beneficial to introducing students to the world of academic research and accompanying professional societies and meetings. The experience that students gained through this project helped prepare them for success in their future graduate programs and careers and thus provided a lasting impact on these students’ professional development. 

The results of the research were disseminated through multidisciplinary conferences on decision neuroscience, human–computer interaction (HCI), and information systems. Some specific conferences include the ACM CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems, Symposium on Usable Privacy and Security (SOUPS), USENIX Enigma Conference, Gmunden Retreat on NeuroIS, International Conference on Information Systems (ICIS), and the Cognitive Neuroscience Society annual meeting. In addition, we published our findings in several of the top journals in the field of information systems, including MIS Quarterly, Information Systems Research, Journal of Management Information Systems, Journal of the Association for Information Systems, and others.

In addition to the publications, conferences, and presentations to tech companies, we worked with the BYU public relations team to facilitate the dissemination of the results through local media outlets and beyond. We also shared relevant findings in courses on information security and neuroscience at BYU. Finally, the results are publically available via the Web at neurosecurity.byu.edu.
